I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2004 Country Programming Mission, the Government of the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help the Baoding municipal 
government (BMG) prepare a project—Integrated Ecosystem Management and Environmental 
Protection of the Baiyangdian Lake Catchment—to be financed by an ADB loan and a Global 
Environment Facility (GEF) grant. The technical assistance (TA) was included in the PRC country 
strategy and program for 2005. In March 2005, a Fact-Finding Mission visited the PRC to hold 
discussions with BMG staff, and reached an understanding with the PRC Government on the 
detailed objectives, scope, costs, implementation, and financing arrangements for the TA.1 The 
Project will support BMG in restoring and protecting the economic and environmental services of 
Baiyangdian Lake using the integrated ecosystems management approach.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Baiyangdian Lake in Hebei Province is the largest remaining semiclosed freshwater body in 
the northern part of the PRC. The lake lies in the middle reaches of the Daiqinghe River basin2 and 
ultimately discharges into the Bohai Gulf, Yellow Sea. Much of the upstream catchment totaling 
31,500 square kilometers (km2) lies within Baoding municipality and all of the lake body is located 
in  Anxin  and  Xiongxian  counties  of  Baoding.3  The  lake  has  a  surface  area  of 366  km2  and 
comprises a series of natural low-lying depressions and reed marshes. While nine rivers and/or 
channels flow into Baiyangdian Lake, only two have regular but decreasing flows, namely, Fuhe 
and Juma rivers. 
3.  Historically, the lake served many environmental and economic services and was described 
as the “kidney” of northern PRC. Because of its strategic position as a sink in the Daiqinghe River 
basin, it is a critical floodwater retention catchment of rainfall water inflows and surface runoffs for 
about 72% of the basin’s area. Specifically, it regulates floodwater discharges and water levels, 
and  moderates  waterlogging.  It  is  likewise  a  pathway  for  transport  of  substances  especially 
nutrients that help contribute to the purification of water and the regeneration of nutrients. The lake 
is also economically important, especially for the more than 100,000 people residing on the lake’s 
wetlands  and  peripheral  zones,  providing    them  with  their  main  sources  of  livelihood  (e.g. 
freshwater fishery, reed production and tourism services), water for drinking and irrigation, and 
major transportation routes. The open water and aquatic beds of the lake serve as spawning 
grounds and feeding habitats for a diverse array of fish and other animal species. As a large body 
of water, the lake also moderates the local and regional temperature and thus has an effect on the 
microclimate of its surroundings.  
4.  Baiyangdian Lake and its upper watershed in the Taiheng Mountains support significant 
biodiversity of regional and global significance within the Daiqinghe River basin. The lake and its 
associated wetlands are primarily important as a refueling site for migratory birds on the east 
Asian-Australasian flyway. Seven globally threatened bird species are regularly sighted in the area. 
The Taiheng Mountains, which contain most of the last remaining natural forests in Baoding, 
support a wide range of rare and endemic animals such as the brown-eared pheasant Crossoptilon

2  The Daiqinghe River basin is one of the nine main river systems within the Haihe River basin. It has a total area of 
43,065 square kilometers (km2) comprising mostly Hebei Province, a small portion of Shanxi Province, and portions of 
Beijing and Tianjin municipalities. The basin can be divided into three major geographic regions: (i) Taiheng Shan 
(mountains from 500–2,286 meters [m] altitude), consisting of the western 40% of the basin; (ii) a low hill transition 
zone of <500 m altitude, covering 10% of the basin; and (iii) the lowland plains occupying 50% of the basin’s land area. 
3  Baoding is the third largest municipality in Hebei Province, with a total area of 22,112 km2 and a population of 
10,830,000 in 2004. The municipality comprises 22 counties and 4 urban districts. Total gross domestic product of the 
municipality in 2004 was CNY11.1 billion. Its growth rate in recent years averaged 11% per annum, with industry as 
the lead sector, followed by services and agriculture sectors.

mantchuricum,  grey-sided  thrush  Turdus  feae,  leopard  Panthera  pardus,  and  golden  takin 
Budorcas taxicolor. It is also recognized as a center of plant endemism in the PRC.  
5.  In the last four decades, the functions and values of Baiyangdian Lake and its catchment 
area have been eroded. Construction of large reservoirs in the upstream catchment has led to a 
dramatic decline in water inflows and surface runoffs into the lake, from an average of 1.73 billion 
cubic meters (m3) of water discharging into the lake in the 1960s down to 0.065 billion m3 in 2002. 
Sediment load had also decreased from 7.1 billion m3 in the 1960s to just 1 billion m3 by 1999.  
6.  The increased water demand for irrigation, industry, energy, and residential uses has been 
a major reason for the water being intercepted and stored in reservoirs. With the demand for water 
exceeding  supply  in  the  Daiqinghe  River  basin,4  the  frequencies  of  no  or  low  inflows  to 
Baiyangdian Lake have become more acute, especially during “dry” years,5 thus contributing to 
increased incidences of temporary drying up of the lake. To compound existing water demands, 
population growth and expanded agricultural and industrial activities in the upstream and within the 
lake areas have increased wastewater discharges, pollutants and sediments from these sectors 
into the lake. It is estimated that half of the pollution sources originate from upstream, while the 
other half comes from the more than 100,000 population residing in and around the lake.  
7.  Activities in the Taiheng Mountains such as logging, quarrying and conversion of natural 
forests and wetlands to agricultural or industrial sites have further contributed to soil erosion and 
land degradation. Large-scale forest fires are also a major threat to the remaining ecosystems in 
the upper catchment.  
8.  A major factor in the diminished role of the lake and its catchment to continue providing 
environmental  services  has  been  the  weak  institutions  and  inadequate  capacities  of  local 
government staff. Poor planning in the use, allocation, and management of the scarce water 
resource coupled with single-sector approaches to forest and soil erosion, limited understanding of 
the lake’s integral role in the larger ecosystem and watershed, and conflicting and overlapping 
roles of government agencies at provincial and municipal levels on the allocation of water have 
resulted in its mismanagement. As the economies of the urban centers grew at an average of 11% 
per year, economic growth considerations became the overriding goal of local governments to the 
detriment of ensuring a sustainable environment. Enforcement of regulatory and policy measures 
for environmental management often gave way to economic growth considerations. That position 
was exacerbated by the lack of public awareness of their responsibility to conserve water, and the 
limited incentives for the private sector to contribute in conserving scarce water resources and in 
protecting the integrity of the lake catchment and its ecosystem. 
9.  The Government of the PRC recognizes the urgent need to address these issues in a 
holistic  manner  using  integrated  river  basin  and  ecosystem  management  approaches.  Water 
pollution control and sustainable use of resources in the water-land ecosystem of Baiyangdian 
Lake have been recognized as one of the country’s priority programs. In 2002, the provincial 
government designated the lake as a Provincial Nature Reserve, and in 2003, an area of 34,000 
hectares of natural forest in the upper catchment was protected. BMG has taken responsibility for 
restoring  and  managing  the  Baiyangdian  ecosystem.  A  comprehensive  pollution  control  plan 
costing CNY8.5 billion of public funds has been developed to reduce pollution in the lake by 17%, 
and improve its water quality to Grade III.6 Policy measures, such as prohibiting textile and paper 
mills to be built within a 5 km buffer around the lake, and the introduction of water pricing have also 
been implemented.

10.  BMG notes, however, that much more needs to be done before the strategic economic and 
ecosystem  functions  of  the  lake  are  restored.  A  TA  to  BMG  could  catalyze  an  enabling 
environment for showcasing an integrated ecosystems approach in water resource planning and 
management7 that is market-based in orientation. It can also serve as prototype for burgeoning 
local economies in packaging intervention measures that utilize scarce water resources of the 
lake’s ecosystem in a way that ensures: (i) ecological sustainability of the lake catchment, and (ii) 
fair and equitable sharing among competing users of present and future generations. The lessons 
learned from this experience will be important to the PRC as the country’s water supply is likely to 
reach its limit by 2030 when the population grows to 1.6 billion, and rivers and lakes are becoming 
drier or more polluted.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The  impacts  of  the  Project  are  improved  water  quality  and  capacity  and  enhanced 
ecosystem functioning of the Baiyangdian Lake catchment. To achieve this impact, the TA will help 
BMG develop an investment proposal comprising investment, policy and institutional measures 
that will address strategically the major pollution problems originating from upstream, midstream, 
and in-lake areas that comprise the Baiyangdian Lake catchment. The intervention measures will 
adopt an integrated ecosystem management approach (footnote 7). Specifically, the TA outputs 
leading to the design of the investment proposal that is suitable for ADB financing will include: 
(i) sector and institutional assessments; (ii) an approved development plan for the Baiyangdian 
Lake catchment; (iii) a technical, environmental, economic, financial and social appraisal of the 
subproject options and their attendant policy measures; (iv) an institutional and capacity-building 
plan;  (v)  a  participatory  gender  plan  and  a  sustainable  livelihood  plan;  (vi)  a  comprehensive 
assessment  of  the  biodiversity  of  the  catchment,  habitat  management  action  plans  and  an 
environmental education and public awareness campaign plan; and (vii) environmental impact 
assessments and management plans as well as resettlement plans. The design and monitoring 
framework for the TA is in Appendix 1. 
12.  A  project  that  integrates  ecosystem  restoration  and  biodiversity  conservation  for  the 
Baiyangdian Lake catchment is being proposed under a GEF grant. The project will complement 
and  incrementally  strengthen  the  overall  goals  of  ecosystem  restoration  and  balance  of  the 
proposed  lending  investment  under  ADB  by  ensuring  that  the  global  benefits  of  biodiversity 
conservation are secured at both the source (Taiheng Mountains) and the sink (Baiyangdian Lake). 
This  GEF  project9  will  focus  on  two  stand-alone  components:  (i)  integrated  biodiversity

management of land, water, and living resources to ensure the resources’ conservation and their sustainable and 
equitable use. It is closely linked to the concepts of integrated water resource management and integrated river basin 
management, which are tools for implementing the integrated ecosystem management approach. (Global Water 
Partnership Technical Advisory Committee. 2000.  Integrated Water Resources Management, Background Papers, #4.

conservation and ecosystem restoration for in-lake and upper catchment areas, and (ii) public 
awareness and education campaigns.  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will be implemented using a participatory approach in designing the project. BMG 
has established a multiagency leading group (LG) at the municipality level that will serve as the 
steering committee during TA implementation. The LG has designated the Baoding Development 
Reform Commission (BDRC) as the lead agency that will oversee the participatory process.  
14.  The initial weeks of the TA will be devoted to conducting a comprehensive sector and 
institutional analysis to determine whether the form of ADB assistance will be more appropriate as 
sector  or  project  lending.  The  subsequent  months  will  be  used  in  evaluating  the  technical, 
economic, financial and social appraisal of the subprojects comprising the project as well as 
improving the development plan of the Baiyangdian Lake catchment.  
15.  The key activities of the TA and the GEF project are: (i) reviewing and analyzing: (a) the 
Baiyangdian Lake catchment as a sector,  (b) its development plans, programs, projects, policies, 
and  institutional  aspects  and  patterns  of  participation  that  impact  on  Baiyangdian  Lake’s 
ecosystem and similar ecosystems in the PRC; and (c) lessons learned from these experiences 
and international practices on integrated ecosystems management approach and water resource 
planning  and  management  of  lake  ecosystems;  (ii)  conducting  stakeholder  consultations  and 
workshops during inception, midterm and draft final TA phases; (iii) assessing the subproject 
options’ technical, financial, economic and social viability to determine the appropriate mix of 
investment and policy interventions that will ensure maximum net benefits vis-à-vis a without-
project scenario; (iv) assessing subproject options for environmental impact, poverty reduction, 
social impact, and involuntary resettlement using ADB guidelines; (v) assessing training needs of 
local government implementers and other stakeholders; and (vi) conducting biodiversity survey and 
comprehensive assessment to detail the existing baseline situation regarding the biodiversity in the 
Baiyangdian Lake catchment. An initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated as $887,000 equivalent, comprising $354,300 in 
foreign exchange and $532,700 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested that 
ADB finance $500,000 and that GEF finance $207,000. ADB will finance $254,300 of the foreign 
exchange cost and $245,700 equivalent of the local currency cost; this part of the TA will be 
financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The expected GEF grant assistance of 
$207,000 will be used to finance $107,000 of the foreign exchange cost and $100,000 equivalent 
of the local currency cost. The GEF grant will be administered by ADB. The Government will 
finance the balance of the local cost, equivalent to $180,000, through the provision of counterpart 
costs and services. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to financing any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 3. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The Executing Agency (EA) will be BDRC. It will: (i) facilitate coordination among the offices 
concerned in BMG, ADB, and TA consultants; (ii) provide access to data and other information that 
will be required in the sector and institutional assessment, and the formulation and development of 
the project; (iii) prepare and submit on time the development plan for the Baiyangdian Lake 
catchment,  the  reports  on  environmental  impact  assessments  and  resettlement  plans  for  the 
subprojects,  and  the  gender  and  livelihood  plans;  (iv) assist  in  preparing  the  training  needs 
assessment and conducting the biodiversity survey; and (v) be responsible for ensuring the active

5
participation of the major stakeholders during TA implementation. The LG will play the steering 
committee role. Its functions are to: (i) oversee the implementation of the investment plan for the 
Baiyangdian  Lake  catchment  area,  (ii)  select  criteria  for  the  subprojects,  and  (iii)  ensure 
institutional coordination at provincial and central government levels.  
18.  The TA will be carried out over 7 months, commencing in September 2005 and will be 
completed by March 2006. A total of 63.5 person-months of consulting services will be required: 
11.5  international  and  51  domestic.  The  international  consultants  will  provide  expertise  in 
integrated ecosystem management, waste management, economics, and wetland management. 
The domestic consultants will have expertise in water resource planning/institutional development, 
sustainable livelihood and social development, agroforest ecology, resettlement, environmental 
impact  assessment,  financial  analysis/finance  management,  environmental  economics,  waste 
management engineering, water resources and/or hydraulic engineering, ecology restoration and 
GEF project development, tourism, and environmental education and public awareness. Terms of 
reference for consulting services are in Appendix 4. ADB will engage a firm in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. The selection process will 
follow  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  simplified  technical  proposal 
procedures.  The  consultants  will  procure  equipment  for  the  TA  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement.  
19.  At the end of the first month, the consultant team will submit to the EA and ADB an 
inception report which will be discussed in a tripartite review meeting and a stakeholder workshop. 
At the end of the fourth month from the start of the TA, a midterm report will be submitted to the EA 
and  ADB,  which  will  include  the  preliminary  findings  of  the  assessment  of  various  project 
components. The midterm report will incorporate the suggestions raised during the second multi-
stakeholder workshop and will culminate in a second tripartite review meeting. One month before 
the end of the assignment, a draft final report will be submitted to the EA and ADB and will be 
presented by the consultant in a major stakeholder workshop. A third tripartite review meeting will 
also be held to discuss the draft final report. The suggestions and comments generated during the 
stakeholder workshop and the third tripartite review meeting will be incorporated into the TA final 
report.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering  the  Global  Environment  Facility  (GEF)  stand-alone  component  of  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $207,000 to be financed by the GEF on a grant basis; 
and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis, to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  preparing  the  Integrated  Ecosystem 
Management  and  Environmental  Protection  of  the  Baiyangdian  Lake  Catchment  Project,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. The President’s approval of ADB administering the GEF 
component of the TA is conditional upon final GEF endorsement of the technical assistance.10

A.   Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or sub-sector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): The subsectors of 
environment and biodiversity, water resource management, and forestry play important roles for ensuring life support systems 
for society in general and for reducing poverty in particular. Freshwater-based ecosystems (including lakes, watersheds, 
wetlands, floodplains, and estuaries) regulate freshwater quality and quantity, and provide crucial habitat for fish, amphibians 
and plant species. The reed beds and other wetland plants remove toxins and excessive nutrients from the water, while 
floodplain wetlands reduce flood risks. Forested headwater catchments also reduce the risks of floods and soil erosion by 
preventing runoff. Cycling the water through forests likewise regulates both local and global climate and maintain local water 
resources. Degradation and overexploitation of freshwater ecosystems, biodiversity and forests will result in loss of these vital 
ecological functions and adversely affect human life. Poor people suffer most from deterioration of ecosystems as they are the 
most directly dependent on ecosystems for their immediate survival.  
In the PRC, the number of lakes and other freshwater ecosystems has declined dramatically. A survey of 514 rivers in the 
PRC in 2000 found that 60 have already dried up, while the water volume in lakes that were monitored was reduced by 14%. 
Moreover, 25% of the 2,000 water sources surveyed recorded water grade quality of greater than III, the minimum standard 
for drinking water. Recently, the Government noted that more than 360 million rural people lacked access to safe drinking 
water. In cities, water shortages have been occurring, resulting in serious health concerns.  
The present use of water in the PRC is 68% for irrigation, 20% for urban areas and industry, and less than one seventh to 
meet the needs of ecosystems to sustain life itself. The unsustainable use of scarce water will have adverse implications for 
the future. Already it is projected that at the present pace of water utilization (with limited recourse for increasing and 
conserving water supply), water supply would reach its limit by 2030. There is an urgent call from the Government to put in 
place a workable integrated ecosystems management approach in water resource use planning and management to ensure a 
more equitable and sustainable use of this scarce resource as well as  restore and protect the ecosystem services of 
freshwater ecosystems.  
In addition, a large number of poor people reside on the periphery of or within the lake/freshwater areas. The majority depend 
on the lake for their income and water source. The lake also serves as the main depository of their wastes. With increased 
pollution in these freshwater ecosystems, the quality of life of lake-based residents has been affected. Incomes derived from 
the lakes (such as reed bed production, fishery, etc.) have declined. Illnesses due to waterborne diseases have risen. There is 
also a need to develop sustainable livelihood sources for the poor who depend on freshwater ecosystems, while restoring and 
protecting the ecological functions of these ecosystems. Intervention measures should at the same time promote integrated 
ecosystem management by local communities to reduce poverty in ways that retain the productive and regenerative 
capacities of ecosystems.  
The proposed project would provide a good case-in-point for showcasing poverty alleviation approaches that would at the 
same time address the pollution contributed by the poor on Baiyangdian Lake, the only freshwater ecosystem in northern 
China, and its upstream (Taiheng Mountains) and midstream catchment areas. A community-based integrated ecosystems 
management approach will be used in identifying the strategic package of investment, policy and institutional measures. 
Project interventions will focus on demonstrating the positive effects of best management practices in sustainable natural 
resource production on biodiversity populations within Baiyangdian Lake and the Taiheng Mountains, such as (i) programs to 
improve reed management, production and harvesting practices within the Baiyangdian lake and similar initiatives for wild 
herbs, fungi and nut harvests in the Taiheng Mountains, (ii) community programs to enhance village environments and 
showcase biodiversity conservation areas at the village level, and (iii) downstream processing investments that are based on 
sustainable natural resource exploitation. Moreover, development of public-private sector partnerships through best practices 
in tourism management will be used to demonstrate the viability of attaining both commercial profit and biodiversity benefits 
and to showcase a sustainable approach for protected area management and biodiversity conservation that can be replicated 
in the PRC’s other environmentally degraded watersheds and water-scarce landscapes with a poor population base.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? Baoding is the third largest municipality in Hebei Province, with a total area of 
22,112 square kilometers (km2) and a population of 10,830,000 in 2004. The municipality has 22 counties and 4 urban 
districts. Total gross domestic product in 2004 was CNY11.1 billion. It is a middle-income municipality with farmers’  per  
capita  income at  CNY2,921 in 2003  (higher than the mean for the PRC and the province),  and a disposable income per 
capita for urban residents of CNY7,139 (slightly lower than the mean for the PRC and the province). Income poverty incidence

Appendix 2  9 
was 7% of the total population in 2000, and is declining. The growth rate in income in recent years, averaged 11% per annum, 
and contributed to the decline in poverty.  
The shares of economic growth have been uneven. Urban per capita income was two times higher than average rural income 
per capita. The lowest per capita income and the poorest households (per capita incomes are just over the official poverty 
threshold of CNY625 per person per annum) are in environment-sensitive areas. In 2000, 679,700 poor people resided in 975 
villages of 11 counties of the municipality; 929 of those villages were in mountainous zones in the northwest of Baoding. 
About 46 of the villages with poor people are located on the periphery and degraded wetland ecosystems of the Baiyangdian 
Lake. The main income sources of upland-based farmers are crop production on slope land, livestock, and vegetable and fruit 
production. The causes of poverty include serious drought, especially in the past few years (it was estimated that 360,000 
farmers slid back to poverty due to the drought), the lack of croplands, limited job opportunities, and low productivity. It was 
not common for local farmers to find off-farm employment in urban areas. The main livelihood of the poor residing in the 
peripheral and wetland areas of Baiyangdian Lake are reed production, fish harvesting and farming (including fish nets and 
ponds), tourism services, small-scale business, and off-farm labor, with high levels of migration to urban areas such as Beijing 
and Tianjin. Access to potable drinking water is a major constraint in these poor villages and most of Baoding municipality. 
Aside from low income, in-lake households face greater risk from waterborne diseases and respiratory illnesses. Although there 
are no records of health indicators, the extreme lack of clean drinking water and serious pollution of the lake (often their food 
source) have become major health hazards.  
Because the poor are located in specific villages with environment-sensitive features, poverty analysis for the project will be 
done at subproject level, and will focus on counties and villages with poor people. Initial assessment showed that of the 12 
counties included in the proposed Baiyangdian Lake catchment area, 3 (Fupin, Tangxian and Laiyuan) are classified as national 
poverty reduction counties where the average household income was below CNY1,980 in 2003. Five more counties (Yixian, 
Laishui, Mancheng, Anxin and Xiongxian) for the proposed project are designated as provincial poverty counties.  
Baiyangdian Lake has 39 in-lake villages, which are surrounded by water in the lake, and 44 semi-in-lake villages, which are 
partly surrounded by water in the lake. An estimated 100,000 persons live in the in-lake villages and another 100,000 persons in 
the surrounding areas of the lake. Of the 39 in-lake villages, 24 villages were listed as poverty villages by Hebei provincial 
government.  
Other poverty areas in the project area are in Shahe irrigation area especially in Quyan County, and the upstream mountainous 
area of Wangkuai and Xidayang reservoirs.  For example, 21 villages with a population of 30,000 persons who are registered as 
poor households are found in Shahe irrigation area in Quyang County. 
The livelihood of poor households residing in environment-sensitive areas is directly threatened by loss of biodiversity. Women in 
particular who depend on the goods and services that ecosystems provide for income bear the brunt of environmental 
degradation. About half of the population on the in-lake villages of Baiyangdian Lake is women. Their income sources are derived 
from fish and duck farming, reed collection and sorting, and small-scale bed and breakfast types of services. Income from these 
sources has decreased in the past years due to the deterioration of the water quality of the lake. The men in these villages have 
sought work outside of their villages, putting more pressure on the women in terms of increased household responsibilities 
(including taking care of the elders) and additional effort expended on declining existing revenue sources due to limited access to 
and availability of skills enhancement programs. Alternative income sources are further hampered by women’s constrained 
access to financial resources. Women’s health is also sacrificed as they, the children, and the elders tend to be more exposed to 
the polluted conditions of the water and poisonous toxins from the lake’s environment.  With less time to spare for recreational 
and other community-based activities, women’s participation in community organizations and commercial networks is severely 
restricted.  
Focus group discussions (with attention to vulnerable groups such as women) will be undertaken to determine the nature of 
poverty  and  the  linkage  of  income  and  non-income  poverty  and  environment.  Participatory  methods  will  be  used  in 
determining sustainable livelihood measures (ecotourism) with strong community and private sector involvement. These will 
be combined with the development of ecological infrastructure and/or policy measures that will address the pollution problems 
and encourage the poor communities to conserve water, protect environmental services, and improve their access to safe 
drinking water. Public education information campaigns will also be incorporated, especially in the Baiyangdian Lake as half of 
the pollution sources originate from the lake-based residents.

D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
Gender analysis: The division of labor by gender is evident in the project area: men are more inclined to conduct outside 
activities, work as migrant labor, and do heavy physical activities, while women are more responsible for and tend to carry out 
farming and household chores. Women have lower education levels than men. Women have also less representation in 
community affairs. To maximize the involvement of women, a gender analysis will be undertaken, including, inter alia, an 
assessment of the roles and relations of gender groups in relation to the ecosystem, the nature and level of involvement of 
gender groups in local organizations that address the ecosystem, the nature and extent of understanding of gender issues 
and environment among environment-related institutions, capacity-building activities, etc.  
Gender and development plan: The project will not have significant negative impacts on women, but a gender plan will need 
to be prepared given that local staffs have low gender sensitivities and lack knowledge and skills for gender analysis and 
mainstreaming of gender concerns.   The gender plan will ensure the equal participation of women in the whole project cycle 
and their commensurate share and involvement in the project benefits: livelihood action and the capacity-building activities. .  
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes      No 
To be undertaken during the TA phase. The output will include (i) gender analysis that looks at, inter alia, knowledge and 
understanding of conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity; how different stakeholders are involved in decision-making 
processes affecting their access to, use of and control over water resources; an outline of the structure of local organizations 
and the ways in which gender has access to and participation in them; and the impact of existing power relations among 
various interests and actors in the community; and (ii) a livelihood action plan.

waste, and sewage projects. The specific tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Assess,  with  guidance  from  the  international  waste  management  expert  the 
technical  merits  of  the  subprojects,  the  sites  allocated  for  the  solid  waste, 
sewage,  wastewater  treatment  and  disposal  subprojects,  and  maintenance 
requirements as these ensure the improvement of water quantity and quality of 
Baiyangdian Lake.  
(ii)  Review  and  quantify  the  associated  costs  and  benefits  resulting  from  the 
subprojects and confirm that the subprojects are based on least-cost options in 
financial and economic terms as well as on quality control. 
(iii)  Review the technical and environmental feasibility of water-saving measures and 
water and solid waste management practices, and recommend cost-effective 
alternatives. 
(iv)  Explore policy and regulatory measures that will encourage reduction of effluent 
recycling  and  introduction  of  clean  production  and  encourage  private  sector 
participation. 
(v)  Review and assess the institutional capacity of the EA and IAs on wastewater 
and/or solid waste management, and make recommendations to address the 
institutional gaps.  
(vi)  Evaluate  the  counterpart  funding  requirements  and  financial  capacity  of 
concerned local governments.

(vii)  Provide technical support to the experts in EIA, resettlement and economics on 
the subprojects.  
(viii)  Provide inputs for sector and institutional assessments as well as in improving 
the Baiyangdian Lake catchment development plan.  
13.  Water Resources/Hydraulic Engineering Specialist (domestic, 3). The specialist will 
have a technical background in hydraulic engineering or related fields of water engineering, and 
groundwater or surface water hydrology planning and design; and at least 10 years of work 
experience  in  planning,  appraisal,  and  technical  design  of  water  resources  projects.  The 
specialist will have the following tasks:  
(i)  Review and appraise the preliminary design and engineering feasibility of the 
canal  connecting  the  Wangkuai  and  Xidayang  reservoirs,  and  recommend 
technically and environmentally feasible and cost-effective alternatives.   
(ii)  Prepare the water balance requirements for and quantify the water requirements 
of the interconnected system, taking into account the required diversions, water 
transfers, and possible water saving and other conservation measures. 
(iii)  Evaluate  the  counterpart  funding  requirements  and  financial  capacity  of 
concerned  local  governments  and  assist  in  the  cost-benefit  analysis  of  the 
subprojects. 
(iv)  Review  the  technical  and  environmental  impacts  of  the  proposed  link  canal 
structure on the downstream water supply area, and discuss the anticipated 
benefits  and  costs  related  to  improved  operation  of  the  system  as  well  an 
assessment of counterpart funding.  
(v)  Provide inputs in the sector and institutional assessments as well as in the 
Baiyangdian Lake catchment development plan. 
C.  GEF-Financed Consultants11 
14.  Wetland  Management  Specialist-GEF  Project  Development  Team  Leader 
(international, 4). The specialist should have relevant academic qualifications in environmental 
management and at least 10 years work experience in wetland management planning; and be 
highly  knowledgeable on GEF project formulation and strategic priorities. The specific tasks are 
as follows: 
(i)  Lead in developing, and have responsibility for delivering a GEF full-sized project 
(FSP)  brief  (and  associated  annexes  and  documentation)  for  integrated 
ecosystem restoration and biodiversity conservation of the Baiyangdian Lake 
catchment. 
(ii)  Manage a participatory process to determine the detailed threats to biodiversity 
within the project area and analyze their root causes. 
(iii)  Coordinate with other international and domestic consultants employed under 
GEF Project Development Facility-B and ADB’s technical assistance to ensure 
that specialist’s inputs to the GEF FSP brief are received in a timely manner and 
meet the criteria necessary for inclusion in the project. 
(iv)  Prepare the incremental cost analysis between the baseline scenario and the 
alternative scenario for input to the GEF FSP brief. 
(v)  Give advice and recommendations to the EA with respect to the GEF budget 
allocations and on all matters pertaining to the FSP brief. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader of the TA in sector and institutional analysis, improvement 
of the Baiyangdian Lake development plan, and in the criteria and selecting

process for subprojects to determine whether it will be a sector or investment 
lending project. 
15.  Ecological Restoration Specialist-GEF Project Development Assistant (domestic, 7). 
The specialist will have a graduate degree on environmental engineering, or related fields, and 
at least 7 years work experience as an ecological restoration and/or wetland management 
engineer. The specific tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Assist in developing and delivering a GEF FSP brief (and associated annexes 
and  documentation)  by  providing  inputs  to  the  review  of  preliminary  project 
design  (GEF  concept  proposal  and  PDF-B  application)  and  supporting 
documents  to  determine  whether  the  proposed  project  meets  the  selection 
criteria of the relevant GEF focal area(s), operational program(s), and strategic 
priority. 
(ii)  Take the lead in developing and designing the specifications for constructed 
treatment  of  wetlands  and  other  ecological  restoration  projects  that  have 
community participation, will reduce in-lake pollution, and will restore and protect 
natural habitats; identifying ecological restoration projects; and be in charge of 
overseeing the protected species assessment and preparation of participatory-
based habitat management action plans. 
(iii)  Together  with  the  social  development  specialist,  assist  in  developing  a 
sustainable livelihood plan. 
(iv)  Assist the deputy team leader in designing the project performance monitoring 
system. 
(v)  Assist the team leader in the sector and institutional assessments as well as in 
improving the Baiyangdian Lake catchment development plan. 
 
16.  Tourism Sector Analyst (domestic, 3). The specialist will have a graduate degree in 
international studies or related fields, and at least 7 years work experience in eco tourism 
development. The specific tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Lead in the development of and have full responsibility for a detailed review and 
market  analysis  of  the  domestic  and  international  tourism  sector  within  the 
Baiyangdian Lake catchment.  
(ii)  Use participatory approaches to arrange private sector workshops to develop 
strategies  for  tourism  development  within  the  GEF  project  and  develop  a 
comprehensive  framework  for  further  development  of  the  environmental 
education and public awareness subcomponents within the GEF project. 
(iii)  Analyze  the  current  baseline  situation  in  terms  of  nature-based  tourist 
destinations,  tourist  flows,  options  available,  pricing  structures  and  revenue 
flows, etc.  
(iv)  Present  the  review  to  the  EA  and  prepare  detailed  recommendations  for 
developing  commercially  profitable  nature-based  tourism  ventures  that 
complement the goal and objectives of the GEF project and will achieve success 
within 5 years after project start.  
(v)  Provide inputs in the sector and institutional assessments as well as in improving 
the Baiyangdian Lake catchment development plan.
